title: 114_hr5556
content: The "Great Bend of the Gila National Monument Establishment Act" establishes the Great Bend of the Gila National Monument in Arizona and outlines various provisions for its management, including tribal use, off-road vehicle regulations, research, education, and visitor services, land acquisition, water rights, and the establishment of an advisory council. The Great Bend of the Gila National Monument is established in Arizona to preserve archaeological, cultural, historic, and natural resources. It consists of approximately 84,296 acres of public lands administered by the Secretary of the Interior. The Secretary may make minor adjustments to the boundaries of the Great Bend of the Gila National Monument to include significant archaeological resources discovered after the enactment of this Act. The map and legal descriptions of any adjustments will be available for public inspection. This Act does not create a protective perimeter or buffer zone around the national monument. The Secretary can make minor adjustments to the boundaries of the national monument to include significant archaeological resources found later. This does not create a protective perimeter or buffer zone around the monument. The management of the national monument allows for minor boundary adjustments to include significant archaeological resources, without creating a protective perimeter or buffer zone. The Secretary of the Interior manages the national monument as part of the National Landscape Conservation System, allowing only uses that further its established purposes. Management objectives include maintaining its undeveloped character and protecting cultural resources and species. The Secretary of the Interior manages the national monument to protect cultural resources, species, and ecosystems. Vegetation management includes inventorying invasive plant species, conducting treatments, and using native plants for restoration. Coordination with the Flood Control District of Maricopa County and neighboring communities is required for invasive species eradication efforts. The national monument is managed to protect cultural resources, species, and ecosystems. Vegetation management involves using native plant species for restoration projects. Grazing is permitted in the monument, subject to laws and consistent with its purposes. Backcountry activities like hunting are supported in the monument. The Secretary of the Interior must develop a management plan for the national monument within three years of the Act's enactment. The plan will address resource protection and include a transportation plan. Consultation with Indian tribes with ties to the area is required. The Secretary of the Interior allows tribal use of the national monument for traditional ceremonies and gathering traditional plants. Tribal use is subject to terms and conditions determined by the Secretary and must comply with applicable law. The Act does not affect the rights of Indian tribes on Indian land, individually held trust land, or treaty rights for access to the national monument. Members of Indian tribes are allowed to use the national monument for traditional and cultural purposes. SEC. 6 limits off-road use of motorized and mechanized vehicles in the national monument to designated roads and trails. SEC. 7 states that the establishment of the monument will not impact military airspace restrictions. SEC. 8 covers research, education, and visitor services. The Secretary of the Interior will provide education and interpretation facilities in the national monument for visitor enjoyment while protecting monument resources. A visitor center will be located in a nearby community, not within the monument boundaries. Scientific research, including climate change research, is authorized to identify and preserve historic and cultural resources within the monument. The Secretary may conduct climate change research to develop management techniques for monument resources to boost resiliency and facilitate adaptation to human-caused climate change. SEC. 9. FISH AND WILDLIFE. This Act does not impact Arizona's jurisdiction over managing fish and wildlife on public lands. SEC. 10. LAND ACQUISITION. The Secretary of the Interior can acquire land within or near the national monument through purchase, donation, or exchange. Acquired land automatically becomes part of the monument. SEC. 11. WITHDRAWAL. SEC. 11. WITHDRAWAL. Federal land within the national monument is withdrawn from public land laws, mining laws, and mineral leasing laws. Renewable energy and transmission development are prohibited in the national monument. SEC. 12. EFFECT ON EXISTING FACILITIES AND RIGHTS-OF-WAY. SEC. 12. EFFECT ON EXISTING FACILITIES AND RIGHTS-OF-WAY. Nothing in this Act terminates or limits any valid right-of-way within the Monument in existence on the date of the enactment of this Act, including energy transport facilities. SEC. 13. WATER RIGHTS. This Act does not affect water rights of the United States, the State of Arizona, or any irrigation district to the Gila River. SEC. 14. ADVISORY COUNCIL. The Secretary will establish the "Great Bend of the Gila National Monument Advisory Council" within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The Council will advise on the management plan and salt cedar/tamarisk removal. It will comply with the Federal Advisory Committee Act and the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976. Members will be appointed by the Secretary, with a limit of 13 members from Category One. The "Great Bend of the Gila National Monument Advisory Council" will consist of 13 members from Category One and an additional 13 members from Categories Two, Three, and Four. These categories include representatives of affiliated tribes, public land ranchers, environmental organizations, and archaeological/historical organizations. The Council membership includes representatives from State, county, or local elected offices, State agency employees, academic institutions, and the public-at-large. The Secretary ensures balanced representation and the Council terminates one year after the management plan adoption.
